alt_statements.statement: I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people, like making schoolwork easier to understand, helping doctors, and solving big problems like pollution, but it should never replace real human kindness or fairness. Adults should make strong rules so AI can’t be used to hurt people, spread lies, or treat anyone unfairly because of who they are. I also think regular people, not just big tech companies, should get a say in how AI is used, so it stays something that helps families and communities instead of controlling them.

As someone who’s spent a career making careful, evidence-based choices about what to bring into a store, I think AI should be treated the same way: a powerful tool we adopt thoughtfully, not something we just let run the show. It can help us solve real problems—like improving healthcare, climate research, and even conservation work that protects bird habitats—but only if we have strong, transparent regulations to keep corporations and governments from abusing it. We need democratic oversight, clear accountability when AI causes harm, and protections for workers whose jobs may change or disappear. In short, AI should serve people and the planet, not the other way around.

I think robots and AI should help people with hard jobs, like doctors or builders, so they don’t get hurt and can fix things faster. But grown-ups should make strong rules so AI can’t be used to cheat, be mean, or spy on people, and they should always have a way to turn it off if it starts doing bad stuff.

As someone who works in a library and sees every day how information shapes people’s lives, I think artificial intelligence should be a helpful tool that makes our work and daily tasks easier, not something that replaces human judgment, relationships, or responsibility. I believe we need clear, enforceable rules—set by a mix of government, independent experts, and everyday citizens—that require transparency about how AI systems work, protect people’s privacy and jobs, and prevent bias or misuse.

As someone who works in insurance claims and sees how messy real-life situations can be, I think AI should be used as a powerful decision-support tool, not a replacement for human judgment or accountability. I want AI systems to be transparent, audited regularly for bias and error, and regulated like other high-impact industries—more like financial or safety oversight than vague “self-regulation.” We should prioritize using AI to expand access to services, reduce drudgery, and improve fairness, but always with legally enforceable guardrails, clear avenues for appeal, and protections for workers and vulnerable communities.

Artificial intelligence should be used to strengthen national security, improve government efficiency, and support American families and workers, but it must always stay under clear human control and reflect our core values. We need strict oversight, strong privacy protections, and serious consequences for abuse—especially by foreign adversaries or big tech companies that don’t share our interests. AI policies should be made by accountable elected officials, not unelected experts, and always respect individual rights, the dignity of work, and the sanctity of human life.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make life easier and more efficient—improving healthcare, strengthening our economy, and helping organizations like the one I worked for serve people better—but it must never replace human judgment, responsibility, or compassion. We need strong, common-sense regulations that prevent abuse, protect privacy and jobs, and keep decision-making accountable to elected leaders and community values rather than to big tech companies or distant bureaucrats.

Artificial intelligence should be used to expand access to opportunity—whether in education, healthcare, or communication—so that people from all backgrounds, including immigrants like me, can benefit from it, not just big corporations or wealthy countries. But given how powerful it is, we need strong, transparent regulations, shaped by diverse communities and guided by principles of justice, accountability, and respect for human dignity, so that AI doesn’t reinforce discrimination or replace human relationships, but instead supports them.

I think artificial intelligence should be like a super helper that makes life easier, like helping doctors, teachers, and scientists solve hard problems faster. But grown-ups should make strong rules so it can’t hurt people, take away too many jobs, or be used for lying or spying. We should always have real people in charge of the most important decisions, because people have hearts and feelings and can care about what’s fair and kind.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a tool to improve people’s lives—especially in education, healthcare, and environmental protection—while never replacing the human relationships and judgment that hold communities together. As a teacher and a Catholic, I believe AI must be guided by strong ethical standards that respect human dignity, reduce inequality, protect the planet, and remain transparent about how decisions are made. To manage the risks, we need democratically accountable regulation, clear rules on data privacy and bias, and strong oversight to keep powerful interests from using AI in ways that harm workers, undermine public schools, or spread misinformation.

Artificial intelligence should be used to solve real problems like climate change, healthcare access, and education, not just to make big companies richer. But because it can be misused—spreading misinformation, invading privacy, or automating discrimination—we need strong, transparent regulations, public oversight, and diverse voices (including young people) involved in setting the rules. As someone who cares a lot about the environment and fairness, I think AI development should be guided by strict ethical standards, open accountability, and a priority on protecting human rights and the planet.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make our communities safer, more efficient, and more secure—whether that’s helping law enforcement analyze data, improving emergency response, or streamlining government services. But it needs strict oversight, clear rules, and real accountability so it never replaces human judgment, undermines individual rights, or gets weaponized against law-abiding citizens. I support strong regulations, transparency in how AI systems make decisions, and harsh penalties for misuse by government or private companies.

As someone who makes a living analyzing systems and improving processes, I see AI as a powerful tool to enhance productivity, reduce drudgery, and free people to focus on more creative, human-centered work. But given its potential to magnify inequality, invade privacy, and spread misinformation, we need robust, democratically accountable regulation—much like we have for financial services or healthcare—along with strict transparency, bias audits, and clear liability when things go wrong. AI should serve the public good, not just corporate profit, and its deployment should be guided by ethical principles that respect human dignity and protect the most vulnerable.

Artificial intelligence can be a useful tool if it helps people live with more dignity, improves healthcare, and supports honest work, but it should never replace the human heart, conscience, and sense of responsibility that come from God and family. Its development and use must be guided by strong moral values, respect for human life, and protection for the poor and vulnerable, with laws that hold powerful companies and governments accountable so they cannot abuse or manipulate people.

I think artificial intelligence should mainly be used to make everyday life more efficient—like improving healthcare, strengthening national security, and helping honest businesses serve customers better—while keeping human judgment in charge. Because the risks are serious, especially around job loss, privacy, and misinformation, AI needs strict, common-sense regulations, strong oversight, and clear accountability, with protections that put American citizens, families, and traditional values first.

Artificial intelligence should be used mainly as a practical tool to make work more efficient, improve safety, and handle difficult or dangerous tasks, not to replace people or make human judgment irrelevant. It needs strong, clear rules from the government and industry to prevent abuse, protect jobs, and keep big companies from using it in ways that hurt ordinary workers and small businesses. Any system that affects people’s livelihoods, privacy, or safety should be transparent, closely monitored, and always have a responsible human decision-maker in charge.

Artificial intelligence ought to be used to make our institutions more efficient, strengthen our economy, and improve everyday services, but it should never replace human judgment, responsibility, or moral accountability. We need clear, enforceable rules—set by elected officials, not tech giants or international bureaucrats—that protect jobs, safeguard privacy, and prevent abuse, while still allowing American businesses to innovate and stay competitive.

Artificial intelligence should be a tool that serves people, especially the vulnerable, and never replaces the human compassion and spiritual care that come from person-to-person relationships. Its development and use must be guided by strong moral and religious values, with clear laws and oversight to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and ensure it does not undermine family, community, or faith.

I’ve lived long enough to see tractors turn into computers on wheels, so I know technology can make life easier if it’s kept in its place. Artificial intelligence ought to be used to help folks—like improving medical care, assisting disabled and elderly people, and making work safer—not to replace human judgment or put people out of a living. We need strict, common-sense rules, with transparency and strong oversight, so big companies and the government can’t use AI to spy on us, control speech, or rig the system. In the end, people, not machines, should stay in charge, and any AI that threatens basic freedoms or human dignity should be reined in fast.

I think artificial intelligence should mostly be used to help people with everyday stuff, like making school easier, improving health care, and helping solve big problems like climate change, but it shouldn’t replace real human connection or jobs that give people purpose. Since it can be misused or go out of control, there should be strict laws and independent watchdog groups to make sure companies and governments use it fairly, transparently, and in ways that respect human dignity and protect the most vulnerable.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life safer and more efficient, like improving healthcare, transportation, and even factory work, but it shouldn’t replace the dignity of honest jobs or human judgment. We need clear, enforceable rules—set by elected officials with input from regular working people, not just tech companies—to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and make sure AI doesn’t just benefit the rich. AI systems should be transparent and accountable, with strong safeguards so they can’t be used to discriminate or manipulate people. In my view, technology ought to serve human values and community well-being, not the other way around.

I think artificial intelligence is a tool, like any other, that can make our lives easier if it’s used responsibly—not something that should be running our lives or taking away our freedom to choose. It ought to help with things like safer roads, better logistics, and healthcare access, but without turning into some big-government surveillance machine. I’d rather see clear, simple rules that hold companies accountable when they screw up or misuse our data, instead of a bunch of heavy-handed regulations that kill innovation. In the end, AI should serve people, not replace our common sense, hard work, and personal responsibility.

As a preschool teacher and a mom, I see how technology can help us, but I also believe it should never replace real human care, judgment, or connection. Artificial intelligence should be used to support people—like helping with paperwork at work or giving students extra learning tools—not to watch us constantly, make unfair decisions, or take away jobs without protection. The government needs strong rules to keep companies from misusing data, to prevent discrimination, and to make sure working families and vulnerable communities are protected first, not treated like test subjects. AI should serve the public good, not just corporate profits.

Artificial intelligence should be a tool that expands opportunity—like improving education, healthcare access, and public safety—especially for communities that have historically been left behind, including Black communities in places like where I grew up. But we can’t just trust tech companies to “do the right thing”; we need strong, transparent regulations, clear accountability when systems discriminate or cause harm, and real input from everyday people, not just engineers and CEOs. Faith-wise, I believe technology should reflect basic moral principles of fairness, dignity, and compassion, which means making sure AI is used to lift people up, not to monitor, control, or replace them without support.

I think artificial intelligence should mostly be used to make practical things work better—like medicine, transportation, and manufacturing—so regular folks’ lives get easier, not harder. But we need strict rules so big companies and the government can’t use it to spy on people, replace every job, or spread lies. Any AI system should be transparent about what it’s doing and who’s responsible, and there ought to be real consequences when it harms people or communities.

I think artificial intelligence can be useful for things like improving healthcare, keeping businesses running smoothly, and making everyday tasks easier, but it shouldn’t be allowed to replace real human judgment, especially in areas like law, policing, or raising kids. The government should set firm rules so big tech companies can’t misuse people’s personal data or push their own agendas through AI, and there should always be clear human oversight and accountability when AI is used.

As someone who’s spent a career locking down systems and watching technology evolve—from vintage hardware on my workbench to modern AI in the cloud—I see AI as a powerful tool that should augment human capability, not replace human judgment or dignity. It ought to be governed like other critical infrastructure: with strict accountability, transparency about how models are trained and used, independent audits for bias and security, and strong regulations that put human rights, privacy, and fairness ahead of corporate profit.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make life safer, more efficient, and more comfortable, especially in areas like healthcare, public services, and protecting our national security. But it must always stay under clear human control, with strong laws to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and keep big tech and the government from overreaching. We ought to move carefully, test things thoroughly, and make sure AI supports human judgment and traditional values, rather than replacing them.

I think artificial intelligence can be a helpful tool, especially for things like medicine, business, and making everyday tasks easier, but it should never replace real human judgment, compassion, or responsibility. We need strong, common-sense laws and oversight to make sure AI doesn’t invade our privacy, spread harmful ideas, or put people out of honest work, and its development should reflect moral values rooted in faith, family, and respect for human life.

I think robots and AI should help people, like doctors and teachers, so they can take better care of us and help us learn more, kind of like helpers but not the boss. Grown-ups should make strong rules so AI can’t hurt people, lie, or take our private things, and they should explain those rules in words kids can understand. I also think people should still listen to God and to their families first, because machines don’t have hearts like we do.

As someone who has spent a life in education and community work, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should be used to expand opportunity, improve public services, and support the most vulnerable, not replace human relationships or judgment. We need strong, transparent regulations and public oversight to make sure AI is fair, respects privacy, and doesn’t deepen inequality or spread misinformation. I believe decisions about how AI is used should involve everyday people—teachers, parents, seniors, and workers—not just tech companies and politicians.

As an older man who’s seen a lot of change over the years, I think artificial intelligence should be used to make life safer and easier—like improving healthcare, helping seniors and people with disabilities, and making work sites and roads safer—but never to replace the dignity of honest work or human judgment. We need strong, common-sense rules, grounded in moral values and respect for privacy, so that AI is guided by people of faith and character, not just big companies or government.

I think AI should be used to make everyday life smoother and more efficient—like better customer service, safer travel, and tools that give people more control over their time and choices, not less. But it needs strong, common-sense rules: transparency about how it’s used, strict limits on surveillance and data collection, and accountability when companies or governments misuse it. I don’t want AI replacing human connection or jobs without a safety net, just supporting people and giving them more freedom to pursue their own goals.

As someone who works in scientific research and is obsessed with technology, I see AI as an essential tool for expanding knowledge, improving education, and tackling complex problems like climate change and public health—especially when deployed in open, evidence-based ways. But precisely because of its power, AI must be governed by strong, transparent regulations that prevent corporate and state abuse, address bias and surveillance, and ensure that the benefits are broadly shared rather than concentrated among a wealthy few.

AI should be a tool that helps people live better lives—like improving healthcare, expanding access to education, and making everyday services more efficient—without replacing the human connection that’s so important in jobs like mine. Pero we really need strong, transparent regulations to prevent bias, protect privacy, and keep big corporations from using AI in ways that hurt workers or vulnerable communities. AI systems should be audited, accountable, and developed with diverse voices at the table so they serve everyone, not just the powerful.

I think robots and computers that can think should help people be safe and healthy, like helping doctors and making sure everyone gets a turn and is treated fair. Grown‑ups should make strong rules so the machines can’t be used to hurt people, be mean, or take away jobs without helping families. People should always be in charge of the big choices, and the robot brains should be checked a lot, kind of like how teachers and parents watch us to make sure we do the right thing.

I think AI should be used to help people with big problems—like making healthcare better, helping with school, and dealing with climate change—but not to replace human connection or basic fairness. Since a lot of decisions made by AI can affect people’s futures, especially kids and marginalized groups, there should be strict rules, transparency, and real consequences when companies or governments use it in unfair or harmful ways.

As a retired teacher, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that can support learning, healthcare, and everyday life, but it must never replace human judgment, empathy, or accountability. We need strong, transparent regulations—created with input from teachers, workers, and vulnerable communities—to ensure AI is fair, protects privacy, and doesn’t deepen inequality. Corporations shouldn’t be allowed to police themselves; government oversight and independent public-interest watchdogs are essential. Used wisely and ethically, AI should serve the common good, not just profit or convenience.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a tool to make our systems safer, more efficient, and more reliable, especially in areas like transportation where lives are on the line. But it should never replace human judgment or accountability. We need strict regulations, independent oversight, and clear standards so we know who’s responsible when something goes wrong, and we should prioritize national security, privacy, and American jobs over the interests of big tech companies.

As someone who spent her life teaching children, I see artificial intelligence as a helpful tool that should support human judgment, not replace it—especially in areas like education, healthcare, and public services. We need clear, enforceable rules to prevent misuse, protect privacy, and ensure that decisions made with AI are fair and transparent, with real people remaining accountable. Society should move forward with AI carefully and thoughtfully, testing it, correcting mistakes, and always keeping human dignity and community well-being at the center.

I think robots and AI should help people, like doctors and teachers, so they can fix problems faster and make life easier, but they shouldn’t replace the important parts of being with real people, like family, friends, and church. Grown‑ups and leaders should make strict rules so AI can’t hurt people or lie, and they should always make sure humans are in charge and using it in a good and fair way.

As an accountant and auditor, I see how powerful AI can be for reducing tedious work, catching errors, and freeing people up to do more meaningful, strategic tasks—especially in industries like mine. But as a Filipino immigrant and a progressive Christian, I’m very aware that unchecked technology can deepen inequality and bias, so I believe AI must be governed with strong transparency rules, civil rights protections, and meaningful oversight from both government and diverse communities. AI should support human dignity and opportunity, not replace our judgment or undermine jobs, privacy, or democracy.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people with important things like school, health, and protecting the environment, not just for making money or replacing workers. Adults, governments, and companies should have strict rules so AI can’t be used to hurt people, spread lies, or spy on families. Since many of us, especially immigrants and kids, don’t get a big say in decisions, there should be simple ways for regular people to understand how AI works and to complain if it’s unfair. AI should be a tool that follows human values, not something that controls our lives.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient and productive—whether that’s in business, healthcare, or even helping folks learn trades—but it shouldn’t replace hard-working people or undermine traditional values. We need strong, common-sense regulations focused on protecting jobs, privacy, and national security, with clear accountability when companies misuse AI. AI systems should be transparent enough that we can see how decisions are made, and our elected representatives—not just tech elites—should have the final say on the rules.

As a physician and immigrant who has seen both the power and the limits of human effort, I believe artificial intelligence should serve as a tool that amplifies human compassion, judgment, and dignity, not as a replacement for them. Its deployment must be governed through transparent, democratically accountable regulations that prioritize patient safety, equity, privacy, and the protection of the vulnerable, with diverse communities—especially those historically marginalized—having a real voice in how these systems are designed and used.

As someone who uses tech every day but still worries about how it affects my kids’ future, I think artificial intelligence should be used to make life easier and fairer—like improving healthcare, education, and accessibility for people with disabilities—without replacing the human judgment and compassion that really matter. We need strong, transparent rules set by government and independent experts, not just big companies, to prevent abuse, protect privacy and jobs, and make sure the benefits of AI are shared widely, not just concentrated at the top.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to help people with real problems, like improving healthcare, education, and protecting the environment, especially in places like the Philippines where resources are limited. But AI can be dangerous if it spreads lies, replaces too many jobs, or is used to control people, so governments, tech companies, and communities should create strict rules together and be very transparent about how AI works and how data is used. As a Christian, I also believe AI should always respect human dignity and never be treated as more important than people themselves.

As someone who drives people around this city all day and spends my nights buried in books, I see AI as a powerful tool that should make everyday life safer, fairer, and more efficient—whether that’s smarter traffic systems, better translation services for immigrants, or more time for people to do meaningful work instead of mindless tasks. But because the risks are real—mass surveillance, job displacement without a safety net, biased algorithms—we need strong democratic oversight: transparent rules, public audits of big tech, worker protections, and clear lines we won’t cross when it comes to autonomy and human dignity.

AI should be like a powerful tool in a good kitchen: it can handle the repetitive, heavy work and help people be more creative, but it should never replace human judgment or responsibility. I think we need clear, simple rules—set by a mix of experts, everyday workers, and communities—that keep AI from hurting people’s jobs, privacy, or safety, especially for folks who don’t have a lot of power. I’m all for technology that gives people more freedom and opportunity, but if a company uses AI, it should be transparent and accountable for what that system does, just like I’m accountable for every plate that leaves my kitchen.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life safer, more efficient, and more affordable, especially in areas like healthcare, insurance, and public safety, but it should never replace real human judgment and responsibility. We need strong, common-sense regulations that protect jobs, privacy, and families, with clear accountability for companies and developers if AI systems cause harm or discriminate. AI should be a tool that reflects our moral values, not a force that changes them, and everyday Americans—not just tech elites or the government alone—should have a say in how it’s used.

I think artificial intelligence should be used to solve big problems like climate change, healthcare, and making education more fair, but it shouldn’t replace real human relationships or common sense. Companies and governments should have strict rules and transparency about how AI is trained and used, with regular independent checks so it doesn’t harm people, invade privacy, or make inequality worse.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make life more efficient and productive—whether that’s in property management, healthcare, or public services—but it should always serve human values, not replace human judgment or relationships. I think the government’s role should be to set clear, conservative guardrails focused on safety, privacy, and preventing abuse, while allowing private businesses room to innovate and compete.

As a music producer and a dad, I see AI as a powerful tool that should support human creativity and help people live better lives, not replace the soul and feel that only humans bring—like the warmth of a vintage record. We need strong, transparent rules so AI doesn’t deepen inequalities, steal artists’ work, or invade people’s privacy, especially in Black communities that already get hit first and helped last. I’m fine with AI helping us make beats, cure diseases, and improve schools, but it has to be governed with real accountability, diverse voices at the table, and laws that protect workers, creators, and families.

As someone who works in manufacturing and cares a lot about both efficiency and well-being, I see AI as a powerful tool that should support people rather than replace them, especially in repetitive or dangerous tasks. But because the risks—like job loss, bias, and surveillance—are real, we need strong, transparent regulations, worker protections, and community input, not just decisions made in boardrooms. AI systems should be audited for fairness and environmental impact, and ordinary people, including immigrants and frontline workers, should have a voice in how these technologies are designed and deployed.

Artificial intelligence ought to be a tool that helps people do their jobs better, not replace honest, hard-working folks or take away their dignity. I’m fine with using AI to improve safety, efficiency, and quality in manufacturing and everyday life, but we need strong, common-sense rules so it doesn’t cost people their livelihoods, invade privacy, or get used to manipulate elections and public opinion. Our elected officials—not big tech companies—should set clear guardrails, with transparency and accountability built in, and keep human judgment and responsibility at the center of every important decision.

As someone who spent years teaching young people to think critically about literature and language, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should support human learning, creativity, and well-being—not replace human judgment or empathy. It needs strong, transparent public oversight, with clear rules to prevent abuses like surveillance, job exploitation, and the spread of misinformation, and ordinary citizens should have a real voice in how those rules are made.

As a nurse and a woman of faith, I believe artificial intelligence should be used to support human dignity, not replace it—especially in healthcare, where compassion and human judgment are irreplaceable. AI can help us detect diseases earlier, reduce errors, and make care more accessible, but its development and use must be tightly governed with strict safeguards for privacy, strong bias protections for Black and immigrant communities, and clear accountability when things go wrong. AI policies should be shaped by diverse voices—not just tech companies—including frontline workers, patients, ethicists, and community leaders.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make our institutions more efficient, especially in critical areas like public safety, infrastructure, and education, but always as a tool guided by human judgment and moral responsibility. We need strong, clear regulations that prioritize transparency, accountability, and the protection of jobs, civil liberties, and family privacy, rather than leaving these decisions to big tech companies alone.

I think artificial intelligence should be like a really smart helper that people use for good things, like figuring out hard problems in science or helping kids learn in school, but not something that replaces real human choices or friendships. Grown‑ups should make strict rules so companies can’t use AI to lie, spy on people, or make things that hurt others, and there should always be real humans checking what AI does so it doesn’t get out of control.

I think robots and smart computers should help people with hard or boring jobs, like cleaning big places, helping doctors, or doing dangerous work so fewer people get hurt. But grown-ups need strong rules so AI can’t be used to trick people, spy on them all the time, or hurt kids, and they should explain how it works in simple words so everyone, even kids, can understand and feel safe.

Artificial intelligence should be treated like any powerful public utility: developed aggressively to improve lives—healthcare, climate modeling, education, even software development—but always with strong guardrails, transparency, and public oversight. We need clear regulations that prevent corporate abuse, bias, and surveillance, with independent audits and meaningful democratic input, so that the benefits are widely shared rather than captured by a handful of tech giants.

As someone who loves music, entertainment, and connecting with people, I see AI as a powerful tool to expand creativity, make life easier, and give more people access to knowledge and opportunities, not just those who are already privileged. But because big tech and governments can also use AI to manipulate, surveil, or replace people unfairly at work, we need strong democratic rules: transparency, data protection, limits on harmful uses like deepfakes and mass surveillance, and real public oversight. AI should complement human talent—not replace our dignity, our social lives, or our freedom.

At my age, I’ve seen new technologies come and go, and I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make everyday life easier—especially in health care, education, and helping people with disabilities—without replacing the human touch we all depend on. We need strong, transparent rules and public oversight so that AI doesn’t deepen inequality, spread misinformation, or invade our privacy, and those rules should protect ordinary people more than corporate profit. As a social liberal and a person of faith, I believe AI should ultimately be guided by values of fairness, dignity, and compassion, with diverse communities involved in deciding how it’s designed and used.

I think robots and AI should help people with hard or dangerous jobs, like fixing big machines or finding sick people faster, but they shouldn’t be allowed to hurt anyone or lie. Grown‑ups, like teachers, churches, and the government, should make strong rules so companies can’t use AI to spy on us, steal our stuff, or make things that could be used in wars.

As someone who runs a childcare center and sees every day how crucial the early years are, I think AI should be used to support people—especially children, families, and educators—by making services more accessible, efficient, and personalized, never to replace real human relationships and judgment. We need strong, enforceable rules that protect children’s data and privacy, prevent bias and discrimination, and ensure that communities—not just tech companies—have a voice in how AI is designed and used.

I think robots and computers that can think should help people, like making things easier at hospitals and schools, but grown-ups should always be in charge of them. My mom and the people at church say we have to be careful with powerful things, so I think there should be rules so AI can’t be mean, lie, or hurt people’s jobs or feelings.

Artificial intelligence should be used to improve people’s everyday lives—things like healthcare, education, and making government services easier to access—while still keeping human judgment and compassion at the center of important decisions. We need strong, transparent regulations and public oversight to prevent abuses, protect privacy, and reduce bias, especially for vulnerable communities. I’d like to see AI development guided by democratic values, with input from ordinary citizens, not just tech companies and politicians.

I think artificial intelligence should mainly be used to make everyday life easier and fairer, like improving healthcare, public services, and access to information, not just to help big companies make more money. But we need strong rules—like we have for medicine and food—so it’s tested, transparent, and held accountable when it harms people, especially vulnerable folks. Government, not just tech companies, should set those rules, and regular people should have a say in what’s allowed and what isn’t.

As a software developer at a public university and a dad, I see AI as a powerful tool that should expand access to education, healthcare, and opportunity—especially for communities that have historically been left out. But that only works if we treat AI like critical public infrastructure: we need strong, transparent regulations, independent audits for bias and safety, protections for workers whose jobs might change or disappear, and real democratic oversight instead of leaving everything up to tech companies.

I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make work safer and more efficient, not to replace people who need a steady job and a fair wage. We need clear, common-sense rules so companies can’t misuse AI to invade privacy, spread lies, or discriminate, and there should always be real people responsible when things go wrong. AI should serve the country and its citizens, not the other way around, and government oversight ought to focus on protecting workers and communities first.

As someone working directly with vulnerable individuals and families, I think AI should be used as a tool to expand access to services—like translating resources, streamlining paperwork, and helping identify people who are falling through the cracks—never as a replacement for human judgment or compassion. Because of the long history of racism and inequality in this country, especially for Black communities, AI systems need strict, transparent oversight, bias audits, and community input baked into their design and deployment. Consistent with my Jewish values of justice and dignity, I believe any use of AI must be guided by the principle that every person’s humanity comes first, even if that means slowing down or limiting certain technologies.

As a preschool teacher and a mom, I see AI as a tool that should support people, not replace the human relationships that really matter—especially in kids’ learning and development. I’m fine with AI helping with things like medical research, lesson planning, and making services more accessible, but it needs strong, transparent rules so it doesn’t invade privacy, spread bias, or concentrate power in the hands of big corporations. We should have democratic oversight, with teachers, parents, and everyday workers at the table, not just tech executives and politicians.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient and safer, especially in areas like education, healthcare, and public safety, but it should never replace human judgment, responsibility, or relationships. We need strong, common-sense regulations that prioritize protecting families, privacy, jobs, and national security, with elected officials—not tech companies—setting the rules. Above all, AI should be guided by moral values and respect for human dignity, not just profit or convenience.

As a teacher, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool to support learning, expand access to resources, and free people to focus on the kind of creative, human-centered work that builds stronger communities. But its development needs firm guardrails: transparent algorithms, strict privacy protections for students and citizens, and public oversight so that the benefits don’t just flow to a few companies. We should prioritize using AI to reduce inequality—especially in education and public services—while putting in place clear accountability so communities, not machines, ultimately shape our future.

As a nurse and educator, I see AI as a powerful tool to expand access to care and education, not a replacement for the human judgment, empathy, and relationships that people rely on in vulnerable moments. I believe we need strong, democratically accountable regulations that prioritize patient and student safety, data privacy, and fairness, with diverse communities at the table—especially those most likely to be harmed by bias or job displacement. AI systems that affect health, education, employment, and civil rights should be transparent, independently audited, and subject to clear legal accountability when they cause harm.

As someone who works hard every day and talks with all kinds of people in my chair, I think AI should be used to make life easier for workers and families, not to replace us or spy on us. It should help with things like education, healthcare, and small businesses, especially in Latino and working-class communities that usually get left behind. But there need to be strong rules so companies can’t misuse our data, discriminate against people, or kill jobs without protections like training and fair wages. Regular people, not just tech CEOs and politicians, should have a real voice in how these systems are designed and controlled.

AI should be used to make everyday systems fairer, more efficient, and more accessible—whether that’s in schools, hospitals, or public services—but it must never replace real human judgment and accountability. We need strong, enforceable regulations that prevent corporations and governments from abusing AI, especially when it comes to privacy, biased decision-making, and surveillance. As someone who works with data, I know how easily numbers can be misread or misused, so AI systems should be transparent, independently audited, and designed with input from diverse communities, not just tech companies.

I think artificial intelligence should mainly be used to make everyday work safer and more efficient, like helping with dangerous jobs, better medical tools, and more reliable infrastructure, not replacing people outright. But I don’t trust big tech or the government to police themselves, so there should be strict laws, clear accountability when AI harms people, and strong limits to keep it from spying on us, taking our jobs unfairly, or being used against our basic freedoms and values.

I think robots and smart computers should help people be safe and make hard things easier, like helping doctors and teachers and keeping bad guys away. But grown-ups should watch them very carefully and make rules so they can’t hurt people or be mean or lie, kind of like how my mom and church teach me what’s right and wrong.

I think robots and computers that can think a little bit should help people, like doctors and teachers, so things are easier and faster. But the grown-ups need to make strong rules so the machines can’t hurt people, be mean, or take away anyone’s job without helping them find a new one. I think there should always be real people checking what the AI does, like parents or teachers watching, so it doesn’t do anything bad or scary.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient—whether that’s improving business operations, medical care, or public services—but it must always serve people, not replace them. We need clear, common-sense regulations that protect jobs, privacy, and national security, with strong oversight from elected officials rather than unelected tech elites or foreign governments.

As someone who serves in the military and depends on both discipline and reliability, I see AI as a powerful tool that should support national defense, critical infrastructure, and everyday services—but never replace human judgment or responsibility. We need strict, enforceable regulations that prioritize security, transparency, and accountability, especially to prevent misuse by adversaries or corporations that put profit over people. At the same time, we shouldn’t overreact in ways that stifle innovation or weaken our strategic advantage; the goal is controlled, well-governed progress, not blind trust or outright fear.

As someone trained to think in models and error bounds, I see AI as a powerful tool to augment human capability—especially in medicine and science—rather than a replacement for human judgment or dignity. We should treat AI like we do other high-impact technologies: with strong, democratically accountable regulation, mandatory transparency about how systems are trained and used, and rigorous, independent auditing for bias, safety, and misuse.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life easier and safer, like improving healthcare, transportation, and public services, but not at the cost of people’s jobs, privacy, or dignity. As someone who works a regular service job, I think workers and local communities should have a real say in how AI is used, not just big tech companies or politicians. The government should set strong, enforceable rules to prevent discrimination, protect data, and keep AI from being weaponized or used for mass surveillance, while still supporting open, ethical research that benefits everyone, not just the wealthy.

Artificial intelligence ought to be a useful servant, not our master—more like a powerful tool to help with practical things like healthcare, transportation, and even making schools run better, but never to replace human judgment and moral responsibility. We need firm, common-sense regulations—set by elected leaders and informed by ethicists, engineers, and ordinary citizens—to prevent abuse, protect privacy, and make sure AI doesn’t push people out of work without a safety net. And above all, our laws and guidelines should reflect respect for human dignity and the value of each person as taught by my faith, not just what is profitable or technologically possible.

As a retired woman living a simple, sustainable life, I see artificial intelligence as a tool that should serve people and protect our planet, not replace human dignity or responsibility. It needs strong public oversight and clear ethical rules, especially to prevent harm to vulnerable people, abuse by corporations or governments, and damage to the environment. I’d like to see democratic input—ordinary citizens at the table—so that AI development reflects compassion, fairness, and respect for human life, rather than just profit or power.

As someone who’s spent a career protecting public health and the environment, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should be harnessed to reduce pollution, fight climate change, and improve healthcare access, not just to boost corporate profits. But we need strong, democratic oversight—clear regulations, transparency about how AI systems work, and strict rules against bias, surveillance overreach, and environmental harms from data centers. AI should serve the public interest, with decisions guided by independent scientists, ethicists, and affected communities, not just tech companies and lobbyists.

As someone who works in tech and sees AI’s potential every day, I believe it should be used to augment human capabilities—making work more efficient, improving healthcare, education, and government services—rather than to replace people outright. But we absolutely need strong, democratically accountable regulation: clear transparency and accountability standards, robust privacy protections, limits on surveillance and autonomous weapons, and aggressive enforcement against bias and discrimination.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make work safer and fairer, not just cheaper—for example, helping prevent accidents on construction sites, improving planning, and opening opportunities for people who didn’t go to college. But the people who build and profit from these systems must be strictly regulated so they can’t replace workers without protections, spy on immigrants, or concentrate even more power in a few hands. Governments, workers, and communities—especially immigrants and low-wage workers—need a real voice in setting the rules so AI serves everyone, not just the rich.

As a special education teacher and a mom, I see AI as a powerful tool that should help us create more inclusive classrooms, better public services, and fairer opportunities—especially for kids and families who are often overlooked. But because it can also amplify bias and concentrate power, AI needs strong democratic oversight: transparent rules, community input (including from immigrants and people with disabilities), and firm protections for privacy, workers’ rights, and human dignity.

I think artificial intelligence can be very helpful if it’s used to support people, not replace them—things like improving healthcare, helping teachers, and making everyday tasks easier. But it must always be guided by strong moral principles, respect for human dignity, and clear rules set by our elected leaders, not by big tech companies alone. We need strict safeguards to protect privacy, prevent misuse, and ensure that humans stay in charge of important decisions, because machines should never have the final say over human life or conscience.

I think robots and smart computers should help people, like making doctors better and helping teachers so kids can learn more and still have fun. But big people should make strong rules so no one gets hurt or left out, and everyone is treated fair, because God wants us to care for each other and use our gifts in a good way.

As a nurse, I see AI as a powerful tool that should support human judgment, not replace it—especially in areas like healthcare, where compassion and ethics are just as important as efficiency. I believe we need strong, democratically created regulations that protect patient privacy, prevent discrimination, and ensure that companies are held accountable when AI harms people. AI systems should be transparent and understandable, so ordinary people and frontline workers can question and challenge their decisions. In a just society, AI should reduce inequality and improve access to services, not deepen existing gaps between those who have power and those who don’t.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make people’s lives easier—improving health care, education, and everyday services—especially for working families and communities like mine that don’t always get the best resources. But it has to be tightly regulated, with strong laws to protect jobs, privacy, and prevent discrimination, and regular oversight by independent experts and the public. We can’t just trust big companies to do the right thing on their own; government and communities need a real voice in how AI is designed and used.

I think robots and AI should help people, like making hospitals better and helping with school, but grown-ups should make rules so they can’t hurt anyone or be used for bad stuff. There should be a lot of testing and watching to make sure AI tells the truth and doesn’t cheat or be mean to certain people. My parents and teachers should be able to understand how it works so they can explain it to kids like me and keep us safe.

Artificial intelligence should be used to make work more efficient, grow the economy, and support things like national defense and healthcare, but it shouldn’t replace people’s responsibility to think, work, and make moral decisions. I think the government’s role should be to set clear, tough rules to prevent abuses—like threats to privacy, job loss without safety nets, or AI being used by bad actors—while still allowing businesses to innovate and stay competitive with other countries.

As someone who has spent a career in higher education, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool to augment human capability, particularly in teaching, research, and public service, but not as a substitute for human judgment, empathy, or democratic deliberation. We should treat AI like a public infrastructure project: subject to robust regulation, transparency requirements, and independent oversight, with explicit protections against bias, surveillance abuse, and corporate capture. Publicly funded research and open standards can help ensure that AI serves broad social and environmental goals rather than narrow profit motives. Crucially, those most affected by AI systems—workers, students, and marginalized communities—must have a real voice in setting the rules that govern their development and deployment.

As someone who works with machines every day and loves tinkering with new tech, I see AI as a tool that should help people do their jobs more safely and efficiently, not replace them or strip away their dignity. AI ought to be used to expand access to education, healthcare, and good jobs, especially for families and people with disabilities, but it needs strong rules so companies can’t misuse data, discriminate, or put profits over people’s well-being. I think we need transparent oversight—like safety standards in manufacturing—so we know how AI systems work, who’s accountable when they fail, and that they’re being used to lift everyone up, not just a few.

Artificial intelligence ought to be used as a tool to make our systems safer and more efficient—whether that’s keeping the lights on, improving infrastructure, or helping communities use energy more responsibly—without replacing the judgment and responsibility of real people. We need strong, enforceable safety standards, clear accountability when something goes wrong, and public oversight so that AI doesn’t concentrate power in the hands of a few corporations or government agencies.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a tool to make work safer, more efficient, and to help us solve real problems, not to replace the dignity of a person earning an honest living. We need strong, common-sense regulations that protect jobs, privacy, and national security, with clear accountability when things go wrong. Decisions about AI shouldn’t be left to big tech or distant bureaucrats alone; they should involve input from ordinary citizens, faith communities, and people who actually understand how things work on the ground. Above all, AI must always serve human life and moral values, not the other way around.
